1: After the Children of Israel had wandered for thirty-nine years
2: in the wilderness, Ferdinand Feghoot arrived to make sure that they would
3: finally find and enter the Promised Land.  With him, he brought his
4: favorite robot, faithful old Yewtoo Artoo, to carry his gear and do
6: The Israelites soon got over their initial fear of the robot and,
7: as the months passed, became very fond of him.  Patriarchs took to
8: discussing abtruse theological problems with him, and each evening the
9: children all gathered to hear the many stories with which he was programmed.
10: Therefore it came as a great shock to them when, just as their journey was
11: ending, he abruptly wore out.  Even Feghoot couldn't console them.
12: "It may be true, Ferdinand Feghoot," said Moses, "that our friend
13: Yewtoo Artoo was soulless, but we cannot believe it.  He must be properly
14: interred.  We cannot embalm him as do the Egyptians.  Nor have we wood for
15: a coffin.  But I do have a most splendid skin from one of Pharoah's own
16: cattle.  We shall bury him in it."
17: Feghoot agreed.  "Yes, let this be his last rusting place."
18: "Rusting?" Moses cried.  "Not in this dreadful dry desert!"
19: "Ah!" sighed Ferdinand Feghoot, shedding a tear, "I fear you do not
20: realize the full significance of Pharoah's oxhide!"
21: -- Grendel Briarton "Through Time & Space With Ferdinand
